skill.name: git-workflow
skill.description: Git workflow with worktrees and conventional commits.
skill.summary: Git workflow with worktrees and conventional commits.
skill.author: Barnhardt-Enterprises-Inc

security_audit.summary: This is a documentation-only skill containing best practices and guidelines. No executable code, scripts, network access, or filesystem operations are present. Only contains markdown documentation with git command examples.

content.value_statement: Teams struggle with inconsistent branches and commits. This skill enforces naming conventions, worktree isolation, and conventional commits for clean history.
actual_capabilities: Create standardized branch names with issue prefixes
Write conventional commit messages with type and scope
Manage feature worktrees for isolated development
limitations: Does not execute git commands automatically
Requires Git and GitHub CLI to be installed
Does not configure remote repository settings

use_cases.title: Enforce team standards
use_cases.description: Apply consistent branch naming and commit message formats across your development team.

use_cases.title: Maintain clean history
use_cases.description: Use conventional commits and linear history for readable project history.

use_cases.title: Isolate feature work
use_cases.description: Use git worktrees to work on multiple features without switching branches.

prompt_templates.title: Create feature branch
prompt_templates.prompt: I need to start work on issue #42 for user authentication. Help me create a properly named branch using a git worktree.

prompt_templates.title: Write commit message
prompt_templates.prompt: I just added a login form component. Write a conventional commit message for this change.

prompt_templates.title: Prepare pull request
prompt_templates.prompt: My feature branch is ready. Help me push the changes and create a pull request that follows the conventional format.

prompt_templates.title: Clean up merged branch
prompt_templates.prompt: My pull request was merged. What commands do I run to clean up the worktree and local branch?

output_examples.input: Help me create a branch for issue #42 adding user authentication

best_practices: Always create worktrees in a dedicated directory outside your main repo
Use conventional commits with type prefix for machine-readable history
Link issues to commits and PRs using issue numbers
Rebase onto main before submitting PRs to keep history linear
anti_patterns: Working directly on main branch instead of feature branches
Using generic commit messages like 'fixed bug' or 'updates'
Using force push to shared branches

faq.question: What tools do I need installed?
faq.answer: Git must be installed. GitHub CLI (gh) is recommended for issue and PR creation commands.

faq.question: Can I use this with GitLab or Bitbucket?
faq.answer: Yes. The git commands work with any Git host. Only gh commands are GitHub-specific.

faq.question: Does this skill modify my git config?
faq.answer: No. This skill only provides guidance. You must manually run commands or configure aliases.

faq.question: Is my data safe with this skill?
faq.answer: Yes. This is a documentation-only skill that reads nothing and modifies nothing.

faq.question: What if my team uses a different commit format?
faq.answer: Adapt the conventions to your team's standards. The skill provides a recommended starting point.

faq.question: How is this different from git initialization tools?
faq.answer: This skill provides workflow guidance, not project setup. It helps maintain consistency during development.
